factoid: The situation cannot be helped if they won't take less.
The old count was forgetting.
The old count must have another entrée.
The old count clutched at his head.
The old count asked who would get him the flowers.
The old count told Dmítri to gallop off to the Moscow estate.
The old count told the factotum to hurry off.
The old count told the factotum to tell Maksím, the gardener, to set the serfs to work.
The old count told the factotum to say that everything from the hothouses must be brought here well wrapped up in felt.
The old count must have two hundred pots here on Friday.
The old count had given several more orders.
The old count was about to go to his little countess to have a rest.
The old count remembered something else of importance.
The old count returned again.
The old count called back the cook.
The old count called back the club steward.
The old count again began giving orders.
A light footstep and the clinking of spurs were heard at the door.
The young count entered the room.
The old count said 'Ah, my boy, my head’s in a whirl!' with a smile.
The old count felt a little confused before his son.
The old count said if the son would only help a bit.
The old count must have singers too.
The old count will have his own orchestra.
The old count asked if they should get the gypsy singers as well.
The old count said the military men like that sort of thing.
The young count said that Prince Bagratión worried himself less before the battle of Schön Grabern than the old count does now.
The old count pretended to be angry.
The old count said 'Yes, you talk, but try it yourself!'.
The old count turned to the cook.
The cook looked observantly and sympathetically at the old count and the young count.
The old count asked the cook, Feoktíst, what the young people come to nowadays.
The cook said 'Laughing at us old fellows!'.
The cook said all the young people have to do is eat a good dinner, but providing and serving it is not their business.
The old count exclaimed 'That’s it, that’s it!'.
The old count gaily seized his son by both hands.
The old count cried that he has got his son.
The old count told his son to take the sleight and pair at once.
The old count told his son to go to Bezúkhov's.
The old count told his son to tell Bezúkhov that Count Ilyá has sent him to ask for strawberries and fresh pineapples.
The old count said that they can't get strawberries and pineapples from anyone else.
The old count said that Bezúkhov is not there himself.
The old count said that his son would have to go in and ask the princesses.
The old count told his son to go from there to the Rasgulyáy.
The old count told his son that the coachman Ipátka knows the Rasgulyáy.
The old count told his son to look up the gypsy Ilyúshka.
The old count told his son that Ilyúshka danced at Count Orlóv's.
The old count told his son that Ilyúshka wore a white Cossack coat.
The old count told his son to bring Ilyúshka along to him.
Nicholas asked if he should bring the gypsy girls along with Ilyúshka.
Nicholas laughed.
Nicholas said 'Dear, dear!'.
Anna Mikháylovna entered the hall with noiseless footsteps.
Anna Mikháylovna had a businesslike, preoccupied, yet meekly Christian look.
Anna Mikháylovna came upon the old count in his dressing gown every day.
The old count invariably became confused when Anna entered.
The old count begged Anna to excuse his costume.
Anna Mikháylovna said 'No matter at all, my dear count.'
Anna Mikháylovna meekly closed her eyes.
Anna Mikháylovna said she will go to Bezúkhov's herself.
Pierre has arrived.
Anna Mikháylovna said they shall get anything they want from Pierre's hothouses.
Anna Mikháylovna said she has to see Pierre.
Pierre forwarded Anna a letter from Borís.
Borís is now on the staff.
The old count was delighted that Anna took on one of his commissions.
The old count ordered a small closed carriage for Anna.
The old count told someone to tell Bezúkhov to come.
The old count said he will put Bezúkhov's name down.
The old count asked if Bezúkhov's wife was with him.
Anna Mikháylovna turned up her eyes.
Anna Mikháylovna had profound sadness on her face.
Anna said 'Ah, my dear friend, he is very unfortunate.'
Anna said if what they hear is true it is dreadful.
Anna said how little they dreamed of such a thing when they were rejoicing at his happiness.
Anna said that young Bezúkhov has a lofty angelic soul.
Anna said she pities him from her heart.
Anna said she shall try to give him what consolation she can.
The old Rostóv asked the young Rostóv what the matter was.
Anna Mikháylovna sighed deeply.
